text: I do this a lot and Lee's approach is the one I take too, so highly recommended :wink:

elements.text: I do this a lot and Lee's approach is the one I take too, so highly recommended

text: @Alex. the broad approach makes sense, but as <@UFTBRB3F1> says, Flumine already does all the heavy lifting for you. Wrapping your head around it and refactoring your approach into the framework isn't trivial and takes some time, but once there, you'll wonder why you ever tried to do it all yourself, Knowing when a game has ended isn't trivial from the market_book unless you just need to know that it's over, with no time constraint, in which case a market.status of CLOSED would do it. If you need something more timely there is an undocumented scores API that BFLW can access for you.

elements.text: @Alex. the broad approach makes sense, but as

If you need something more timely there is an undocumented scores API that BFLW can access for you.

text: from the bf site, can you see where you are in the queue?

elements.text: from the bf site, can you see where you are in the queue?

text: Never needed to do it, but presume it's possible to work out. If I were implementing this my thinking would start with a thought experiment like: there's £100 available, and I add £10, there should be £110 available. If the matched amount goes up by £50, there is now £50 left in front. If the amount available goes down and matched doesn't go up, there's cancelled money in front of me. Available going up is money behind in the queue...

elements.text: Never needed to do it, but presume it's possible to work out. If I were implementing this my thinking would start with a thought experiment like: there's £100 available, and I add £10, there should be £110 available. If the matched amount goes up by £50, there is now £50 left in front. If the amount available goes down and matched doesn't go up, there's cancelled money in front of me. Available going up is money behind in the queue...

text: So I would imagine you can get a sense of how far away you are just by looking at the amount matched and available when you place and tracking matched and available as you go... only issue is if people are cancelling in front of you but people are coming in behind you at the same rate - hard to see you're moving up faster than you think, then.

elements.text: So I would imagine you can get a sense of how far away you are just by looking at the amount matched and available when you place and tracking matched and available as you go... only issue is if people are cancelling in front of you but people are coming in behind you at the same rate - hard to see you're moving up faster than you think, then.

text: <@U012XF5CNPN> Yeah I get that logic, but there are some confusing situations especially when I'm dealing with the site and whatever potential latency there is. I.e. batb is 6, I put  $20 offer at 6.2, and the next update I get says there is $180 available at 6.2. I then put a $20 offer at 6.4, and next update there is $150 at 6.4 as well. Is someone getting in front of me? Behind me? It's hard to say.

The latter you could still favor having to calculate it yourself!

text: I'm probably on the other side of that, it seems the market is best/fairest with more open information, and it seems fair/right that you should be able to see where you are in a queue as you consider whether to cancel or not. But maybe I'm bringing my own bias of that's how it was in the limited things I messed with in HFT.

text: in few examples of exchange trading I saw, the client would get every order that was placed (I think it's called Level 1 or Level 2 market data). With that one can basically recreate the full order book on the cliend side and know exactly the position in the queue (the trick being replicating the matching engine of the exchange perfectly)
